thread.title: 16th-century altarpiece to a coveted rare doll
thread.title_full: 16th-century altarpiece to a coveted rare doll - The Boston Globe

author: Virginia Bohlin
title: 16th-century altarpiece to a coveted rare doll
text:
By Virginia Bohlin Globe Correspondent September 05, 2015
Morphy Auctions
Rare A. Marque doll sculpted around 1914 by Albert Marque and dressed in its original provincial outfit designed by the Parisian couturier Jeanne Margaine-LaCroix is expected to bring $100,000-$200,000 at Morphy Auctions’ sale of the Katie and Paul Hedburn doll and train collections.
Choices ranging from a 16th-century altarpiece triptych to 20th-century works are being offered at Skinner’s Fine Paintings & Sculpture Auction Sept. 11 at 4 p.m. at its Boston gallery.
The more than 7-foot triptych, attributed to the Flemish artist Jan van Rillaert the Elder (1495-1568) depicts the Crucifixion in the central panel, the road to Calvary in the right, and the Entombment in the left. It descended in a Belgian-American family and has a $70,000-$90,000 estimate, the auction’s expected top price.
Continue reading below
This also is the estimate for “Vessels in Rough Seas off the Dutch Coast,” an unsigned oil on panel dated “1628” and attributed to the Dutch artist Simon Jacobsz de Vlieger (1601-53), famous for marine paintings some of which are in the collection of the National Gallery in London.
Highlighting the auction is “Night Music Opus #24” ($40,000-$60,000), a 1989 acrylic and pasted papers on canvas mounted on board by Robert Motherwell, who was born in 1915 in Aberdeen, Wash., and died in 1991 at his summer home in Provincetown.
A leading member of the abstract expressionist movement, Motherwell was honored in May with a two-day centennial celebration presented by the Provincetown Arts Association & Museum and the Fine Arts Work Center in conjunction with the Dedalus Foundation that was founded by Motherwell in 1981 to foster public understanding of modern art and modernism.
Other top offerings include paintings by Maurice Brazil Prendergast (1858-1924), the Canadian-born New York artist, who lived for a time in Winchester and is known for his Boston and New England beach scenes, and by Daniel Ridgway Knight (1839-1924), the Philadelphia-born plein-air (in open air) and genre artist, who spent most of his career in France. Prendergast’s circa 1916-19 “Bathers on a Rocky Shore,” a 11¼-by-15 ⅝ -inch watercolor, pencil and pastel on paper and Knight’s 47¼-by-37¼-inch oil on canvas of a young French woman holding a puppy in a terraced garden overlooking the Seine River, each have a $50,000-$70,000 estimate.
Also in the sale is a 35-by-45¾-inch oil painting “Old Bridge at Quimperle,” a town in Brittany, by Knight’s son Louis Aston Knight (1873-1948), who was born in Paris and like his father spent most of his life and career in France, moving permanently to the United States in 1940. The painting, formerly in the collection of Citizens Bank in Providence, has a $12,000-$18,000 estimate.
Among the works by contemporary artists is “The Great Transaction (In Two Parts)” a mixed media sculpture by the Nashville-born New York Pop artist Red Grooms (b. 1937). Dated “75-81,” the 138-inch-long, 78-inch-high sculpture of six figures standing on a wagon depicts the historic sale of the island of Manhattan by the Lenape Native Americans to Peter Minuit and a group of Dutch colonials on May 24, 1626, reputedly for then about $24 in exchange for cloth, beads, hatchets, and other goods. The estimate is $12,000-$18,000.
Skinner, Inc.
Andy Warhol’s “African Elephant,” a 38-by-38-inch color screenprint from his “Endangered Species,” 1983, will be offered with a $30,000-$50,000 estimate at Skinner’s Fine Prints & Photographs Auction Sept. 11 in Boston.
Preceding the sale of paintings and sculpture is the noon Fine Prints & Photographs Auction highlighted by “African Elephant” from “Endangered Species,” 1983, by Andy Warhol (1928-87). The 38-by-38-inch color screenprint on museum board is number 38 in an edition of 150-plus proofs printed by Rupert Jasen Smith, New York, and is expected to bring $30,000-$50,000.
It is one of 10 prints consigned from the collection of Citizens Bank in Providence, with the other estimates ranging from $800-$1,200 for “Biological Garden” a color lithograph with etching, screenprint, and collage on Japan paper from the 1975/76 edition of “Imaginations and Objects of the Future” by the Spanish artist Salvador Dalí (1904-89) to $7,000-$9,000 for “Ship,” a lithograph in brown on paper by Ed Ruscha (b. 1937), the Omaha-born California artist.
“Evening Wind,” a 1921 etching signed by the noted Truro artist Edward Hopper (1882-1967) and inscribed “$30,” depicts a woman getting into bed with curtains flapping at an open window and has a $15,000-$20,000 estimate. It is from a group of six prints, including two etchings by the French artists Édouard Manet (1832-83) and Henri Matisse (1869-1954), each with a $4,000-$6,000 estimate, which descended in the Lanier banking family of Indiana and New York.
Prints from the estate of Worcester artist Terri Priest, who died in 2014 at 86, include a 1982 color lithograph by Pennsylvania-born Alice Neel (1900-84) of a bikini-clad girl with a large floppy red hat standing on a beach (estimate $800-$1,200), while photographs from Priest’s collection include “Four Sided Dune #2, Death Valley, California” (estimate $3,000-$5,000) taken in 1954 by William Garnett (1916-2006), the California landscape photographer who specialized in aerial photography.
Topping the photographs is the circa 1930 “Nude With Ropes” by the Czech photographer Frantisek Drtikol (1883-1961). The estimate is $12,000-$18,000.
www.skinnerinc.com/auctions/2841B , www.skinnerinc.com/auctions/2840B
. . .
One of the rarest, most coveted and expensive dolls, a circa 1914 A. Marque doll, will be offered with a $100,000-$200,000 estimate at Morphy Auctions Sept. 10-12 auction in Denver, Pa., featuring the doll and train collections assembled over 60 years by the late Katie and Paul Hedburn of Chicago. Katie died in 2010 and Paul last February.
The 22-inch doll, described by some as the “Holy Grail of doll collecting” is one of 100 fashion dolls sculpted by the French sculptor Albert Marque (1872-1939), who gained fame in the early 20th century for his lifelike sculptures of children.
The bisque dolls made in girl-boy pairs were commissioned by the Parisian couturier Jeanne Margaine-LaCroix (1868-1930), who dressed them in outfits designed to represent regional French royalty or peasantry. Only about 20 of these dolls, which are considered artistic works of French culture, are known to exist.
Last year a No. 27 A. Marque boy doll was sold in Naples, Fla., by Theriault’s, the Annapolis, Md., company specializing in appraisal and auction of antique dolls and childhood ephemera, for $300,000, the highest price ever paid at auction for any doll.
The doll from the Hedburn collection, which numbers some 120 dolls of various periods, styles and countries, was purchased in the late 1960s or ’70s for $7,000 at an antiques fair in Chicago.
Following the sale of the dolls, the collection of Hedburn trains, which includes American Flyer, Ives Lionel, Boucher, Voltamp, and early Carlisle & Finch examples as well as European 1-, 2-, and 3-gauge trains, will be auctioned.
Collections from another consignor include gas-powered race cars, boxed comic character and outer space-themed watches, and rare lunch boxes highlighted by a Superman lunch box with an $8,000-$12,000 estimate.
www.morphyauctions.com/auctions/view/09102015-09122015-ToysMarblesDollsFiguralCastIron
Virginia Bohlin can be reached at vbohlin@comcast.net.
